Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
transformed_texts:
Life in my metropolitan area is characterized by a dynamic blend of urban and residential spaces. Commercial hubs, teeming with a diverse array of businesses, are interspersed throughout residential pockets. These businesses encompass a wide spectrum, from bustling offices to a vibrant mix of retail stores, restaurants, and entertainment venues.  The culinary scene is particularly flourishing, with an abundance of new dining options constantly emerging. While large, established brands hold a prominent presence, independent boutiques are gaining increasing popularity, dotting both shopping malls and the city streets, often within walking distance of otherwise tranquil residential areas. 

Green spaces, such as parks, are scattered throughout the city, providing areas for recreation and community gatherings, particularly for families with young children. The neighborhood itself reflects this urban tapestry, encompassing a notable concentration of diverse cultural groups.  One specific area boasts a thriving LGBTQ+ community, alongside a prominent Orthodox Jewish community and a significant population of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union.  

Venturing slightly beyond the immediate neighborhood, the city reveals a mosaic of diverse ethnic enclaves – Korea Town, China Town, Little Armenia, and many others, each a few miles away, yet sometimes requiring significant travel time due to the city's extensive traffic congestion.  While certain points of interest may be within close proximity, the sheer scale of the metropolis often necessitates reliance on automobiles for transportation, leading to notorious traffic issues, particularly during peak hours.  

Despite the prevalence of automobiles, the city has witnessed a surge in recent construction, with numerous high-rise apartment buildings springing up. This influx of new residents, however, has sparked concerns about increased population density and traffic burdens. 

Interestingly, the city offers a range of housing options, catering to diverse preferences. While high-rise apartments are prevalent, residential areas also feature a variety of traditional houses, ranging in size, as well as smaller apartment buildings and condominiums.  Single-family homes and duplexes are also common, ensuring a diverse housing landscape even within my immediate neighborhood.  The neighborhood itself is a mix of ages, and while I cherish memories of my childhood spent playing with neighborhood friends, today's community lacks the close-knit feel it once possessed.

The character of my neighborhood is quite distinctive. While most residences are traditional single-family homes, there are a few intriguing examples of properties that have been divided into two separate living spaces, albeit still connected. My own dwelling boasts a modest front yard and a small driveway positioned to the side. Like many others in the area, its architectural style evokes a sense of a bygone era, a time when suburban living symbolized the quintessential American dream. This dream, once seemingly inclusive and readily embraced by the nation, now appears to be receding. However, my neighborhood, along with countless others, continues to stand as a testament to its enduring allure, whispering a message that the dream persists, though perhaps in a more nuanced form.

Despite a palpable shift in optimism, and a noticeable decline in the meticulous upkeep of front yards, the neighborhood retains a certain charm. Each driveway typically houses at least one vehicle, and children still engage in carefree play, their world seemingly confined to the immediate surroundings. The local public school, a venerable institution with nearly nine decades of history, continues to operate, inspiring aspirations in the younger generation while simultaneously evoking a sense of nostalgia in its older patrons.

Though churches are sparsely distributed and often appear deserted, the local basketball courts remain vibrant hubs of activity. Despite their diverse appearances, the homes share a common feeling of familiarity. A prominent supermarket, known as "Super A," has been owned and operated by a large Yemeni family, who may constitute the neighborhood's only Arab residents. The majority of the inhabitants are African American. Wide streets accommodate the children who frequently engage in games of football, pausing only to allow passing vehicles to navigate safely. 

Many residents have deep roots in the community, spanning multiple generations, and their stories often recount a time when the neighborhood fostered a strong sense of interconnectedness. A karate school once flourished, but its popularity waned with the decline of martial arts movies in popular culture, eventually transforming into a pharmacy. The neighborhood also boasts a small movie theater that specializes in showing classic films at discounted prices. While younger patrons tend to dismiss it due to its lack of newly released titles, it remains a favored destination for the older residents, who appreciate the opportunity for a night out at an affordable price.

A major expressway traverses the town, although its entry and exit points are located in the neighboring town. There was a previous petition to establish an exit within our own town, a proposal supported by the younger generation but vehemently opposed by the elders, who believed that such an addition would irrevocably alter the character of the community. Their influence ultimately persuaded the city council to reject the request.

Currently, a new high school is under construction, and the community is engaged in a spirited debate over the selection of a mascot. In my view, a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be the most fitting representation of our unique town.

This neighborhood might not grab your attention at first. Tucked behind a shopping center, it doesn't scream "desirable living."  You'd likely think it's just another ordinary residential area. However, venture past the old, unoccupied Whole Foods and behind the hotels that only see visitors during the summer for family gatherings, and you'll uncover a thriving community.  

Hidden along these streets are several apartment complexes, arranged side-by-side like carefully disassembled Russian nesting dolls. The first ones you encounter have been featured in the news for some unsavory reasons, so we'll steer clear of those. Appearances can be deceiving, after all. But the apartments next to them, and the ones beyond those, reveal a hidden world largely unknown to those who live nearby.

Opposite these complexes stands a small satellite campus of a community college. It's a quiet place, with students arriving in the morning, coffee in hand, yawning as they begin their day. The iron gates creak open, letting them in one by one, while commuters sometimes express their frustration at the morning traffic delays caused by the increased student flow.

The road eventually intersects with a residential street. On one side lies a park, and on the other, a rehabilitation center for people recovering from injuries. The center has inviting porch furniture and a ceiling fan that gently circulates the warm summer air. 

Children play in the park across the street, running and giggling as they do cartwheels and handstands. Bees buzz lazily among the flowerbeds lining the road. Elderly residents walk their dogs along the path, sometimes grumbling at the teenagers skateboarding nearby, while nodding politely at the teenage girls gathered around the playground equipment, whispering about boys and the latest online trends.

Near the park is a strip mall with a variety of businesses. There's a sushi restaurant with affordable prices, a swimming supply store, and a nail salon tucked between them. You could conveniently get a manicure, stock up on pool supplies, and enjoy some hibachi chicken all in one place - the perks of a strip mall! There's also a self-serve frozen yogurt shop, a popular spot for teenagers, who often grab a cup, loaded with toppings, before heading to the park to skateboard and vape, convinced it's the coolest thing to do.

This neighborhood is a slice of Americana, a piece of history preserved in the slow-paced South where things seem to remain unchanged, even time itself.

The car sped past fields of corn stretching out as far as the eye could see. "Where is everything?" she asked, her voice tinged with surprise. I smiled, knowing the vastness of the landscape would be a shock to her.  Coming from a town where the grocery store was a stone's throw away, she'd never experienced this kind of open space.  

Seeing her awestruck, I shared stories of growing up in rural Ohio, hoping to give her a sense of where I came from. As we drove down a narrow country road, she finally understood. 

We passed a quarry, its waters reflecting the sky, and just beyond it lay a small development. Brick and stucco houses lined the road, each with a generous half-acre of land meticulously cared for. Spring brought an explosion of color from carefully planted flowers, while the native trees showcased their seasonal transformations. Gleaming Mercedes-Benz cars, the epitome of luxury, lined the driveways, freshly washed and gleaming in the afternoon sun.

Continuing on, we approached my grey stucco home. Our Korean neighbor, always with a friendly wave, tended his lawn, his voice occasionally rising above the hum of his mower. He was a beloved figure in the neighborhood, despite his sometimes quirky ways, a doctor in his past life, now blending into the landscape with his John Deere mower.

My house, set back from the road, had geese in the side yard, chased playfully by our energetic terrier.  A small stream, fed by the quarry, flowed behind the house, its melody punctuated by the croaking of bullfrogs and the distant moo of nearby cattle. A handmade wooden bridge led to a secluded oasis behind the house where trees, herbs, and wildflowers thrived. This was my childhood playground, a place of endless adventure, from building elaborate tree forts to "hunting" squirrels and rabbits with my neighborhood friends.

Winter in our small town was harsh but beautiful. The once vibrant green yard transformed into a stark, empty expanse, the trees stripped bare, their branches etched against the sky. A snowfall would blanket the landscape overnight, creating a winter wonderland. My sister and I, always ready for a snowball fight, would build elaborate igloo-like forts, our backyard transformed into a battleground. We were a force to be reckoned with, our snowy arsenal ready. In our own private winter haven, we escaped into a world of make-believe, oblivious to the world outside.

Portland, Oregon, has a unique identity tied to the concept of "weird."  This term isn't simply a label; it's deeply ingrained in the city's culture.  On a building that somehow manages to function as a pizzeria, bar, music venue, and strip club, the slogan "Keep Portland Weird" is proudly displayed.  While some see it as a nostalgic nod to the city's past – a time when it was less known and more affordable, fostering a vibrant array of subcultures – others interpret it as an invitation: come to Portland and embrace your individuality.

Despite the influx of residents from California and the ongoing construction boom, Portland retains its distinct character.  "Weird" doesn't necessarily mean an uncritical acceptance of everything; it signifies a willingness to embrace the unconventional.  It doesn't mean Portland is devoid of modern conveniences or societal challenges. Like many cities, Portland grapples with issues like consumerism and economic disparity.  

However, "weird" also encompasses a sense of lightheartedness and a resistance to taking oneself too seriously.  My neighborhood, typical of many in Portland, is a vibrant tapestry of colorful houses, flourishing gardens overflowing with flowers, herbs, and vegetables, and a peculiar tradition known as "free boxes." These boxes, usually cardboard but sometimes plastic bags, appear on sidewalks during the summer months, filled with cast-off items that might just be a treasure for someone passing by.  Clothes, books, and all sorts of unexpected finds can be discovered within them.

The magic of exploring a Portland neighborhood lies in these small moments of serendipity. This sense of wonder and possibility is what Portland represents to me, though I'm just one small facet of its diverse tapestry of "weirdness."  While some may not partake in the unconventional rituals of finding clothes in free boxes, others might be drawn to goat yoga or cheering on the city's soccer team, the Timbers.

Portland is a city of dreamers and doers, those who pursue their passions and those who dream of doing so while enjoying a pint at a local brewery. It's a city that acknowledges its challenges, such as drug addiction, often rooted in mental health issues, and a persistent homelessness problem exacerbated by the city's social services, which, while better than in many places, are still inadequate.  The non-homeless population struggles with a range of emotions towards the homeless, oscillating between empathy and resentment, a common human dilemma rather than a uniquely Portland quirk.

The northern peaks are always a constant presence. They stand sentinel, observing the sun's daily migration across the heavens. Regardless of how preoccupied I become with my studies or daily responsibilities, they remain steadfast, unaffected by the ebb and flow of life's challenges. On days when stress threatens to overwhelm me, they seem to beckon my attention. When I turn towards them, I find solace, a moment of respite for my troubled mind. They offer a quiet strength, a reminder that I can face each day as it comes.

My introduction to this place began during my first year of college. The mountains, rising majestically north of the campus, were the first thing that truly captivated me. While the university itself boasts its share of picturesque scenes – grand buildings, serene ponds, and ancient trees – it's the mountains that hold a special place in my heart. The town itself has its own unique charm. Quaint cafes, where countless hours were spent fueled by caffeine and late-night study sessions, dot the landscape. A short walk or bus ride takes you to the downtown area, where the faded brick facades of restaurants and office buildings whisper tales of bygone eras. Here, the town exudes a vibrant energy, rivaling that of its bustling urban neighbor.

This lively atmosphere, however, doesn't extend far. Just past the library, the tranquility of small-town life returns. This juxtaposition of contrasting environments, existing in such close proximity, infuses the city with a captivating allure, inviting exploration and discovery. Within this unique setting, countless memories are forged, each tied to a specific place. Whether it's strolling past the rusty swings in the park with friends after a grueling all-nighter or navigating the crowded downtown streets to catch a movie at the university-sponsored theater, each experience leaves its mark.

Yet, like all places, this town holds both cherished and painful memories. The ponds, in particular, serve as a backdrop for both quiet reflection and tearful moments of despair in the depths of an existential crisis – an experience I've had more than my fair share of. Observing the turtles, ducks, and insects, each playing their part in the intricate web of life, I find myself pondering my own purpose, grappling with the complexities of existence.

One such walk past the pond, the park, and the quintessential suburban homes led me to a main street. As the sun's rays bathed the palm trees in golden light, painting the sky in vibrant hues, I realized I was walking north. And there they were, the mountains, as constant and steadfast as ever. They soared above the hazy blue and yellow expanse, their presence dwarfing even the tallest buildings on the horizon. In that moment, their silent strength stirred within me a renewed sense of perseverance.

A trip to Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, is easily accessible thanks to the city's robust public transportation system, a common mode of getting around New York.  Being a distinctly urban neighborhood, you'll find the bustling energy of the city surrounding you.  One of the most striking features of Bensonhurst is its diverse cultural landscape, particularly its strong Asian influence. Over the last twenty years, the area has experienced a significant influx of Asian residents, resulting in an abundance of Asian-owned businesses lining the streets. Supermarkets and laundromats are particularly prevalent, and for good reason. Residents rave about the quality of goods and the competitive prices offered by these establishments, making them highly convenient options.  In fact,  in the immediate vicinity where I reside, four Asian-owned supermarkets are within a short walking distance of each other,  underscoring the ease of accessing essential groceries. 

While Asian residents form a significant part of the neighborhood's fabric, Bensonhurst remains a melting pot of cultures. Immigrants, alongside their first and second-generation American-born children, contribute to the vibrant tapestry of the community.  Beyond the Asian-owned businesses, the neighborhood boasts a recently renovated park, offering a variety of recreational facilities.  Complete with ten basketball courts, a spacious field suitable for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for children, and even a water fountain for cooling off during the summer, the park caters to a wide range of interests. 

The neighborhood's residential landscape is predominantly composed of two-family houses, with co-op and condominium apartments also present.  While the people are generally friendly, noise can be a persistent issue.  Driving habits, with cars often playing loud music or accelerating abruptly, can disrupt the peace, especially in the mornings.  Although Bensonhurst is generally considered safe, it's wise to exercise caution, particularly during nighttime hours, as unpredictable behavior can occur.  Instances of petty crime, such as bullying and theft, have been reported, though thankfully, these incidents are not frequent.  

One final note: while New York City has ordinances against dog fouling, unfortunately, not all residents adhere to these rules. Be prepared to encounter dog waste on sidewalks and pathways.

Life in my community is characterized by a distinct topography.  Our neighborhood is built upon a series of inclines, with my residence situated atop the most pronounced elevation. Locals affectionately refer to it as "workout hill" due to its popularity among joggers seeking a challenging ascent.

Sidewalks are a rarity in our area, forcing residents to navigate the roadways. The pavement displays signs of wear and tear, with several pitted areas that present a potential hazard for motorists.  Overhead, the power lines and telephone wires appear somewhat dilapidated, a consequence of frequent inclement weather events that often result in downed branches and debris.

The landscape is dominated by towering evergreen trees, a feature that is met with mixed feelings by the populace. While these trees provide a sense of serenity, many residents strive to remove them, contending that they obstruct the view of the distant ocean. This desire for panoramic vistas has led to an architectural trend of elevated homes with expansive glass facades, particularly on the upper levels, designed to maximize the vista of the bay.

The sunsets are truly breathtaking, with the water shimmering beneath a fiery orange sky. However, the region's frequent cloud cover often obscures the sun, casting a veil of haze over the landscape. Dampness is a persistent companion, fostering the growth of moss on various surfaces, from rooftops and automobiles to railings.  The dampness is so pervasive that even parked vehicles are susceptible to a verdant overgrowth.

The neighborhood's demographic skews towards older residents, many of whom are retirees. While children are not as prevalent, the presence of pets, particularly dogs, is ubiquitous. These canine companions are frequently observed traversing the lawns or engaged in playful chases.  

The presence of wild rabbits is another characteristic feature of the area. They are a source of annoyance for gardeners due to their tendency to unearth plant roots and burrow into lawns. However, my feline companions find them to be a delightful source of entertainment.

The avian population comprises a diverse array, from tiny sparrows and hummingbirds to the occasional majestic hawk or eagle, which is often chased away by the resident crows.  

While retail establishments are absent in our immediate vicinity, a short downhill trek to the waterfront reveals a few restaurants specializing in fresh seafood. The beach itself is limited, but the rocky shoreline provides a source of amusement as residents launch stones into the water. The bay's modest width allows for clear views of the opposite shore, even on misty days.

Our home is situated on a residential street in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's conveniently located between two state highways, resulting in a higher volume of traffic than I personally prefer. However, beyond that, it's a peaceful neighborhood. There's a sense of stability here, with few residents moving in or out, allowing me to become acquainted with most of my neighbors. Daily life revolves around typical routines, with residents tending to their yards and attending to everyday tasks. During the winter months, we enjoy sledding down a nearby hill. Our house, situated at the corner of the street, provides a vantage point where we observe the comings and goings of the neighborhood residents and become familiar with the vehicles they drive. Any unfamiliar cars draw our attention. Many neighbors engage in walks, either for exercise or to walk their dogs. Children, as one would expect, can be found playing on their bikes. As we work from home, our family spends a considerable amount of time within our residence. We consist of four individuals: myself, my spouse, and our two daughters, aged eleven and fourteen. Consequently, our neighbors are accustomed to our presence and movements. We actively participate in outdoor activities, even braving the occasional rainy day. Occasionally, we gather on our back deck for barbeques, filling the air with the delightful aroma of grilled food. The sound of lawnmowers is a frequent occurrence from March to October, a constant reminder of the lush greenery that thrives in our neighborhood. 

Our community is characterized by a significant number of trees, a legacy of its wooded origins. While this provides ample shade, it also means dealing with a seasonal influx of leaves in the fall, necessitating raking and burning. I personally find the scent of burning leaves to be a comforting sign of autumn's arrival.  Recently, we've experienced a lack of traditional winter weather, making it feel more like an extended fall. Our garage, located at the rear of our house, means we rarely use the front entrance unless someone is visiting, which is infrequent. I enjoy spending time in the garage, working on my truck or other projects. With the garage doors open, I feel a stronger connection to the neighborhood. During holidays, the neighborhood tends to be quiet. Thanksgiving brings gatherings of families with visitors from out of town, resulting in a surge in parked cars. Similar occurrences happen during holidays like Mother's Day and Christmas. Overall, I find living here to be enjoyable. If not for the through-traffic, it would be truly idyllic.

My neighborhood is situated in the heart of the high desert, a landscape characterized by its extensive expanse of arid terrain.  The prevailing color palette is brown, a visual constant that those unfamiliar with this environment may find challenging to comprehend.  Well-maintained lawns, however, serve as testaments to the dedication of their owners, who invest considerable resources in their upkeep.  

When I first resided here in the 1990s, the housing density was considerably lower, with properties spaced further apart.  While this pattern persists to some extent, there has been a noticeable increase in new construction in recent years. This trend has led to a gradual transformation of the area, with a growing resemblance to an urban center. This shift, however, is not unique to our locale, as many communities are experiencing similar changes.

The residents of my neighborhood, for the most part, are friendly and welcoming. As with any sizable population, there are both positive and negative aspects to the community. I am fortunate to be surrounded by a number of amiable senior citizens, which contributes to the overall pleasant atmosphere. The retail options are predominantly chain establishments, such as discount grocery stores and general merchandisers. For a broader selection of goods, one would need to venture outside the immediate vicinity. I don't often encounter upscale retailers or similar establishments.

Based on my observations, the dominant industry in our city appears to be construction.  This is likely due to the fact that the city is still undergoing significant development, with ample undeveloped land available for new projects. This rapid growth, however, gives me a sense of unease, as I prefer the current pace of development. Having previously lived in a large metropolitan area, I have no desire to return to that type of environment.

Speaking of construction, it is the field in which I am employed full-time. I work as a drywall and ceiling installer.

One of the aspects I most appreciate about my home is the diverse wildlife that inhabits the high desert. The unique climate and topography of this region have created challenging ecosystems that require protection and preservation. It is essential for human residents to educate themselves about the non-human inhabitants of this environment in order to coexist peacefully and harmoniously.  My family and I have successfully adapted to sharing our space with wildlife. My three children are particularly fascinated by lizards and desert insects, and as I write this, they are outside attempting to capture various specimens.

Victorville offers a variety of attractions for visitors. It provides a distinctive experience, especially for families seeking an introduction to the desert. If your visit coincides with the annual San Bernardino County Fair, you are in for a treat. This event offers a delightful blend of activities and entertainment that embodies the Victorville spirit.  A short trip to nearby Wrightwood allows you to witness snow-capped mountains and participate in winter sports activities.

For those interested in the natural history and cultural heritage of the high desert ecosystem, the Victor Valley Museum is a must-visit. It houses a collection of geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that shed light on the development of society and industry in Victorville.

My living situation might not be typical. While many applicants probably hail from traditional neighborhoods with single-family homes, my "hood" is a bit different. I consider my on-campus residence hall to be my primary community, with the surrounding campus acting as an extended neighborhood.  

Though unconventional, my campus community shares some similarities with those classic neighborhood concepts. Just like any other area, there are various types of dwellings, people from all walks of life, and essential amenities like stores and a park.

Let's start with the "houses."  My campus offers three main housing options. There are dorm-style residences, which are the most prevalent and house hundreds of students in shared rooms. Then there are apartments, typically accommodating 2-4 people per room and scattered across several floors. Lastly, a limited number of houses are available for rent to affiliated individuals, often those who have graduated.

The campus is a melting pot of cultures and ages, reflecting the institution's commitment to diversity. Faculty and staff often reside in the houses, while newer students gravitate towards dorms, and older students tend to favor apartments.

Speaking of amenities, my campus boasts a variety of dining options, along with unique stores selling school merchandise and groceries.  Essentially, everything needed is readily available within the campus boundaries. 

There's also a central park where students can relax and socialize, kept safe and clean by the community itself.

Reflecting on my decade-long residency in this neighborhood, I can offer a glimpse into my experiences. Initially, I confess, the transition from Riverdale to Stockbridge was bittersweet. Leaving familiar faces and cherished memories was undeniably difficult, prompting a few tears. However, my parents, driven by their unwavering desire to provide the best for my sister and me, believed this move represented a significant step forward. We sought a more favorable living environment, a higher-caliber educational institution, and a community that offered broader opportunities. 

Over time, I adapted to this new setting, forging lasting friendships and encountering a few challenges along the way. While I haven't established deep connections with most neighbors, I cherish the relationships I've formed with Mr. Glen and his family, as well as Dennis, who resided next door. Their warmth and welcoming nature have made them feel like an extension of our own family, and I'm deeply grateful for their presence. 

One particularly memorable occasion was Mr. Glen's remarriage. Witnessing their joy and celebrating alongside them was a truly special experience. It instilled in me a longing for a similar kind of love and commitment in my own future.  The wedding reception was a whirlwind of laughter, dancing, and shared moments. I fondly recall a small, white strap that Ms. Veda, Mr. Glen's wife, tossed into the crowd. I had the fortunate experience of catching it, although I missed out on the bouquet! 

The neighborhood itself has a labyrinthine quality, but with the aid of GPS navigation, I've begun to explore its hidden corners. My explorations have often led me to gatherings with friends like Kason and Curtis, where we indulged in video games and embraced the joys of youth. 

Seeking solace and a connection to nature, I often find myself at the local park. The tranquility of the surroundings calms my spirit and brings a sense of peace. I sometimes practice balancing on tree branches, armed with a bokken wooden sword, reinforcing my dedication to martial arts. 

The neighborhood boasts both basketball and tennis courts, although I haven't actively engaged in those sports lately. They remain a reminder of a time when I participated in tennis lessons with my best friend, guided by the experienced instruction of Mr. Graves. We were pushed to our limits, but the memories remain a testament to the fun and camaraderie we shared.  

Reflecting on my time here, I'm filled with a sense of gratitude for the experiences, friendships, and personal growth I've encountered. While I cherish the past, I'm eager to embrace the future and all the possibilities that lie ahead.

My residence is situated in close proximity to my university, a fact I greatly appreciate. The neighborhood primarily consists of apartment buildings, interspersed with a few casual dining and entertainment establishments that offer reasonably priced options. One bar recently underwent a rebranding and, while now more upscale, doesn't necessarily compromise on the quality of its offerings. The local demographic is predominantly composed of students and individuals with modest incomes, reflecting the affordability of the apartment rentals. 

The presence of a nearby elementary school contributes to a lively atmosphere with numerous families in the vicinity. While I maintain cordial relationships with my fellow residents, I prefer to keep my social circle limited.  A noticeable scent emanating from a neighboring unit, a result of frequent cannabis use, has prompted the building management to install an air purifier near the entrance, a situation that my partner and I find both amusing and slightly condescending.

The surrounding structures display a mix of architectural styles, with some showcasing modernized interiors despite their exterior appearances.  Across the street, newly constructed apartment complexes boast contemporary designs, though I personally find them lacking in quality due to their hasty construction. Despite their higher rental rates, I perceive them as overpriced for the value they provide, a consequence of their desirable proximity to campus.

A budget-friendly eatery within a five-minute radius serves its fare on disposable plates and primarily relies on microwave cooking. Adjacent to it stands a gas station, whose employment practices have garnered mixed reviews. However, recent city-funded road improvements have enhanced the neighborhood's aesthetic appeal with wider sidewalks, verdant medians, and attractive landscaping.

My apartment building is strategically positioned amidst a grove of trees, although some have been removed, leaving behind a few stumps. The tree canopy is significantly denser in my immediate surroundings compared to the less-forested streets further down. Behind my building lies a tree line bordering another apartment complex. While I reside on 42nd Street, the adjacent 43rd Street presents a contrasting image with dilapidated sidewalks, unkempt buildings, and a higher concentration of trees, potentially employed as a visual camouflage for their less-appealing appearance. Crime incidents have been primarily concentrated in an apartment complex on 43rd Street, though I wouldn't attribute the blame solely to them, as other apartment buildings in the area also experience their share of criminal activity. Nonetheless, despite these challenges, I find my current residence satisfactory. Its affordability and proximity to essential amenities, including the university and convenient public transportation, outweigh any minor drawbacks.

My residence is situated in a quaint community of duplex-style homes arranged along a cul-de-sac. While they share a uniform aesthetic characterized by yellow exteriors, white porches, and green metal roofs, the spacing between them creates an illusion of individual houses. The residents, a close-knit group, often gather in the evenings at the end of their driveways, engaging in friendly conversation while the neighborhood children play. This sense of community is a welcome respite from the pervasive technological world we live in, reminiscent of a simpler time.

Our surroundings are graced by expansive fields, verdant trees, and a picturesque sky adorned with billowing clouds. However, this idyllic setting has recently been punctuated by the unexpected threat of tornadoes. We were recently alerted by the unmistakable sound of sirens, prompting us to seek shelter. I found myself in my bathtub, seeking refuge with my youngest dog, my purse, and a few pillows. My larger dog, more apprehensive, remained in the living room, barking nervously. The neighborhood fell eerily silent, punctuated only by the sound of hail battering the ground. 

The storm's passage left a trail of steaming pavement, a testament to the rapid temperature drop from 92 to 75 degrees. The hail melted instantly upon contact with the hot asphalt. As the clouds parted, a double rainbow appeared, a breathtaking spectacle that I captured with my camera to share with loved ones. The streets remained tranquil for a while before residents gradually returned, resuming the everyday rhythm of life. Children played, mothers chatted as dinner simmered, a testament to the resilience of our tight-knit community. 

It's been a delightful experience settling into this friendly neighborhood, a world away from my previous home in New Hampshire. I particularly cherish the melodic southern accents that fill the air. While all the duplexes share a similar exterior, each interior is unique, with some being surprisingly compact.  

I enjoy taking leisurely walks through the expansive field behind my residence, leading to a picturesque pond. Deer often graze in the area, and the mornings are serenaded by the croaking of a giant bullfrog. This idyllic location, just forty minutes from Charlotte, feels like a small village nestled amidst the countryside. The sound of roosters crowing from nearby farms greets each morning, further enhancing the tranquil atmosphere. Even the local donkeys add to the charm with their evening braying.  I feel incredibly fortunate to have discovered this hidden gem of a neighborhood.

My transition to this neighborhood coincided with the start of eighth grade. Initially, forging connections proved challenging, but I ultimately developed close friendships with two individuals – one residing two houses down and the other on my street.  While they've since relocated, the memories we shared endure. Remarkably, the majority of the original residents remain, lending a sense of continuity.  

My neighborhood embodies the quintessential American suburban aesthetic.  Two-story houses dominate the landscape, and the sounds of children's laughter fill the air on weekends and warm days.  A tranquil atmosphere pervades most weekdays. I've always encountered nothing but friendliness and helpfulness from my neighbors.  It's a place where privacy is respected, yet assistance is readily available when needed.  

This sense of security extends to online deliveries; I've never experienced any incidents of packages going missing from my porch.  The inherent trust within the community is deeply comforting.

A short walk from my home lies a park that holds a special place in my heart.  Many cherished memories have been made there – playing basketball, football, and baseball with neighborhood friends. While a football mishap resulted in a memorable (and painful) elbow to the nose, the positive experiences far outweigh the negative.

Nowadays, my visits to the park are primarily focused on spending time with my cousin's younger children, who find endless joy in swings, slides, and other playground staples. Their enthusiasm for the park evokes a wave of nostalgia for simpler times.

The neighborhood's diversity extends beyond its residents. A short distance away, a vibrant culinary scene awaits, offering a variety of cuisines, from Chinese and Indian to Mexican and Italian. While the convenience of food delivery apps like GrubHub and DoorDash has become increasingly popular, local fast food chains and pizza places remain neighborhood staples. 

Essential amenities abound, including multiple dry cleaners, a Walgreens, a CVS, and a popular Jewel-Osco grocery store.  Adding to the neighborhood's richness, there's even an Indian-owned store catering to those who seek authentic flavors.

Overall, my neighborhood is a place I deeply appreciate.  Witnessing the challenges others face with their neighbors through social media and news reports only reinforces my gratitude for the sense of community and support I've found here.

Living in Johnston feels like stepping back in time. It's a small South Carolina town, not particularly remarkable at first glance, but its agricultural roots run deep.  The town proudly wears its nickname, "The Peach Capital of the World," on its welcome sign, a testament to the rolling fields of peach trees that dominate the landscape. Cattle farms are also common, adding to the rural charm.

Homes are scattered throughout the town, mostly two-story structures with metal roofs or gray shingles, built to withstand the summer heat. Many are set back from the road, leaving space for livestock or gardens.  

The heart of Johnston revolves around a single four-way intersection,  where a lone stoplight regulates traffic and the town's limited commercial options gather.  Fast food choices are surprisingly diverse for such a small place: Hong Kong, a family-run Chinese restaurant; Fiesta Mexican Restaurant; and Gary's, a familiar burger chain. A recent loss for the town was the closure of its local pizzeria.

For everyday necessities, residents rely on Maxwell and Halford Drug, a quaint family pharmacy known for its Cherry Coca-Cola.  The only grocery store in town is Independent Grocers Alliance, or IGA, which, while small and somewhat pricey, still serves the community's needs. Many, however, prefer the convenience of a larger selection offered by Walmart in the nearby town of Batesburg-Leesville. 

Dollar General reigns supreme in Johnston, a bustling hub for everyday essentials that draws a constant stream of customers. Possibilities Furniture & More, a long-standing furniture store owned by a beloved community member, adds a touch of local charm.  Attached to the furniture store is Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a pet grooming service offering a range of options from daycare to bathing.

While Johnston lacks a traditional downtown, its medical services are well-equipped. Both a doctor's office and a veterinary practice are conveniently located outside the main town center. Education is provided by Johnston Elementary School, after which students attend middle and high school in the neighboring town. 

Recreational opportunities are currently being expanded with the construction of a new 2.5-acre park, aiming to provide more space for families and attract new residents. Currently, the town's main draw is its tranquility and sense of community. While it lacks the amenities of larger towns, Johnston offers a quiet life, a charming atmosphere, and a strong sense of belonging.

My initial awareness of this neighborhood came from an unexpected source: a podcast about missing persons. It was a strange coincidence, considering the area's high rent, with apartments consistently surpassing a thousand dollars a month. Neither I nor any of my friends had ever heard of this particular story. Perhaps it's a reflection of the financial struggles many of us face. I'm acquainted with a few friends who find themselves overwhelmed by the cost of living, relying on tears to navigate the nights. Expenses are a constant challenge, but we've honed our resourcefulness over time. We've learned to appreciate the unique aroma of secondhand treasures and forgotten clothing, unearthed from flea markets. The scent of adulthood, we discover, permeates even the most thorough wash, clinging to our belongings like a persistent memory. In this particular neighborhood, the allure of thrifting is undeniable. Within a short walk, you'll find three distinct stores catering to the secondhand enthusiast: two charitable thrift shops, a well-stocked library, a rare book haven, and a curious collection of artifacts.

Downtown, the city pulsates with energy. Cars and pedestrians converge, transforming the streets into a bustling tapestry of life. Yet, step into any of these thrift stores, and the outside world fades away. Regardless of the constant flow of people and vehicles, a profound tranquility envelops the space, inviting you to lose yourself in the quiet contemplation of forgotten treasures. It's a haven for those seeking refuge from the city's frenetic pace. Every year, the influx of both people and cars intensifies, a testament to the city's relentless growth. They call it a "developing city," a term that evokes both promise and uncertainty. Its rapid expansion, fueled by its role as the headquarters for a prominent e-commerce giant, is evident in its evolving infrastructure and ever-expanding boundaries. It reminds me of New York City: a place where individuals are driven by their own aspirations, navigating their lives with a sense of independence. Solitude is valued here, and one is rarely burdened by intrusive inquiries. It's a stark contrast to the South, where outward expressions of concern are often interpreted as genuine care.

Here, personal boundaries are respected, and privacy is paramount. You can choose to remain introspective, shielding yourself behind a carefully constructed facade, and the city will continue its relentless march forward, indifferent to your internal world. It's a vibrant and dynamic place, teeming with life and energy. The sounds of the city permeate my own apartment, courtesy of the talented pianist next door and the two amateur singers who reside upstairs. They provide a constant soundtrack to my days, a testament to the city's creative spirit. In a way, we've formed a unique community within this urban landscape. We come together to celebrate milestones, mourn losses, and offer support during times of need. It's a testament to the human spirit's ability to find connection amidst the anonymity of city life.

I feel fortunate to call this place home. The majority of my neighbors are kind and welcoming, creating a sense of belonging that transcends the superficiality of modern living. We strive to be considerate of each other, offering assistance and sharing resources whenever possible. It's a small but significant gesture that fosters a sense of mutual respect and appreciation.

While this city might be characterized as a massive, impersonal concrete jungle, it's the warmth and generosity of individuals like my neighbors that remind me that I haven't lost sight of what truly matters.

My neighborhood has a distinct character, one that most would describe as suburban.  The influence of a homeowner's association is evident throughout.  Arriving, you're greeted by a uniform landscape of well-kept single-family homes, a testament to the association's dedication to order. Front yards, while varied in specific details, share a common theme: manicured lawns, decorative stone accents, and compact driveways.  Mature trees punctuate the scene occasionally, and two-car garages are the norm. 

The streets are a testament to the community's commitment to shared upkeep, showcasing freshly paved concrete and a lack of the usual potholes or blemishes.  While most homes are single-story, a scattering of two-story dwellings adds visual interest.  

Interestingly, mail delivery deviates from the standard setup.  Instead of individual mailboxes, a centralized cluster, reminiscent of apartment complexes, houses all deliveries, accessible via individual keys.  Package lockers, also situated in this central location, further reinforce the association's emphasis on uniformity.

Located on the outskirts of a nearby city, our neighborhood blends suburban charm with elements of rural living.  This unique positioning has resulted in a generous expanse of land dedicated to community amenities.  Multiple swimming pools, meticulously maintained and secured by gates, are available for residents' enjoyment.  A network of walking trails, perfect for dog walks or leisurely strolls, meanders through the landscape, providing ample opportunity for exercise without venturing beyond the neighborhood.

The majority of residents are retirees, contributing to a strong sense of community and safety.  A smaller contingent of middle-aged and young professionals adds diversity to the mix.  The city itself, surprisingly expansive in terms of population, retains a small-town ambiance.  Essential amenities, including a single, well-functioning mall, are readily accessible within a 15-minute drive.  This mall, while not sprawling, caters to a wide range of needs, from high-end grocery stores offering organic produce to budget-friendly outlets with streamlined operations.

Overall, my neighborhood offers a safe, well-maintained environment with a distinctly suburban character.  The presence of community amenities like pools and trails enhances its appeal. While shopping centers may not be within immediate walking distance, a short drive grants access to a diverse array of retail options.

My upbringing has taken place in a town nestled just outside the bustling suburbs of a major city.  While my immediate neighborhood, situated on the eastern edge of town, faces economic challenges, it's far from desolate.  Housing costs are lower in this area, attracting residents with limited financial means.  However, the community spirit is strong, with neighbors readily greeting one another with smiles and friendly exchanges.

Though the crime rate here is slightly higher than in other parts of town, it remains relatively manageable.  There have been isolated incidents of violence within our vicinity over the past decade, including a few shootings and a tragic homicide.  Sadly, a neighboring family experienced the devastating loss of their son in a shooting near a local establishment last year.  Thankfully, our family has not been directly impacted by crime beyond the occasional minor theft from our porch.

The pervasive opioid crisis, which has gripped many communities across the nation, has also left its mark on our town.  Fentanyl overdoses have taken a heavy toll on lives.  However, there are dedicated resources in our town striving to combat this epidemic. Addiction rehabilitation centers and Narcan training programs for families and friends of those affected offer hope and support.

Despite these hardships, our town boasts numerous positive attributes. My son's elementary school is truly exceptional, with a dedicated staff, from the principal to the teachers and support personnel. He has thrived in this nurturing environment, free from bullying, and genuinely enjoys attending school.  The active Parent-Teacher Organization (PTO) organizes numerous events throughout the year, fostering family involvement and enriching the educational experience.

The school recognizes the economic realities faced by a significant portion of our community, with over 20% of the town's population living below the poverty line.  To ensure no child goes hungry, the school provides free breakfast and lunch to all students.  Financial constraints are never a barrier to a child's education, with reasonable costs for school fees, supplies, and field trips.

The City Council and its staff have made commendable efforts to enhance the town's appearance, including road resurfacing, landscaping, and the refurbishment of city parks.  Unfortunately, the majority of these improvements have concentrated in the town center and on the west side, where commercial areas and traffic flow are concentrated.  My neighborhood on the east side, while possessing its own charm, has been somewhat overlooked, a point of concern for many residents.

Overall, I find contentment in residing in this town.  The people are friendly, the schools are excellent, there are ample shopping options to meet our family's needs, and our home, while modest in value, provides us with comfort and adequate space.  We've called this town home for over 16 years, and it holds a special place in our hearts.

My neighborhood possesses a unique character. Situated on a hillside, it's surrounded by buildings steeped in history. I reside in a seven-story apartment building directly across from a historic theater, and a short distance away, nestled down a sloping street, is a popular arcade bar. On warm summer evenings, you'll often see a queue of people eager to enter. A few blocks further up lies the nearest urban park, surprisingly expansive for its location. It's enclosed by a concrete perimeter, featuring towering steps integrated into the wall. During the harsh winter months, individuals experiencing homelessness set up their tents in organized rows along the sidewalks and the wide steps. While snowfall is infrequent, the region experiences heavy rainfall, particularly in midwinter, making it challenging to stay warm. By clustering their tents together in the city center rather than in isolated areas, they manage to retain more heat. They also benefit from convenient access to a nearby family center, the only one for miles, where they can access showers and bathing facilities.

However, what truly captivates me about my city isn't its architectural grandeur—the imposing structures, the intricate designs that adorn the various levels of the rolling hills descending towards the ocean. It's the spirit of its people that I find most compelling. Hilltop, once infamous on the West Coast for gang violence, still carries the echoes of its turbulent past. Even three decades later, stories circulate about federal officials and the DEA's relentless efforts to quell the unrest. The community remembers. Tales are passed down through generations, reaching even newcomers like myself, of those bygone days.

Despite its reputation as one of the city's more challenging neighborhoods, the residents work diligently to maintain its cleanliness. They remain deeply invested in their community, their block. While there's a warning that white individuals shouldn't venture out after dark, I believe this advisory stems from outdated perceptions and ingrained societal conditioning. Perhaps my complexion, allowing me to blend in, or perhaps Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, a fellow traveler acutely aware of the persistent reminders that plague our nation—reminders of racism, cultural biases, and the unfounded assumptions born from ignorance and fear, even within a city supposedly embracing diversity and inclusivity.

One thing is certain: no matter how far I may wander, Hilltop will always be my home. I feel invigorated walking its streets at night, encountering individuals who have more readily and generously offered me a jacket than attempted to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have extended their hours to accommodate me charging my phone when I was caught in a downpour. It's a place where, feeling invisible, I've sought refuge against concrete storefronts on bleak, dreary evenings, only to have someone stop, meet my gaze, hand me a five-dollar bill, and tell me I am beautiful and valuable.

My hometown lies in the heart of rural Michigan, a place where rolling farmland gives way to charming, smaller tourist destinations.  You won't find the typical big-city chains here – no sprawling malls, no ubiquitous stores like Walmart or Target, not even a familiar Applebee's.  Getting around requires a car, but the beauty of the surroundings more than compensates. My community is nestled between two stunning lakes: the vast expanse of Lake Michigan and the picturesque Lake Charlevoix. Every direction you turn offers a glimpse of sandy shores and inviting waters.

The character of my neighborhood reflects the essence of small-town living. Homes aren't crammed together in identical rows; each one possesses its own unique charm. Some have undergone modernizations, while others proudly showcase their age. Many boast spacious basements, visible from the street, adding to the distinct character of the area.  Aluminum siding, often in a variety of colors, adorns many of the homes, creating a colorful tapestry along the streets.  

Yards are a prominent feature here, often filled with laughter and life. Trampolines bounce, playsets echo with the sounds of childhood, and some residents cultivate gardens or tend to their livestock.  The homes themselves embody the spirit of hardworking, family-oriented individuals. Children's laughter fills the air as they run freely, while neighbors catch up while walking their dogs or enjoying a leisurely bike ride.  A sense of community thrives, where familiar faces are readily recognized and welcomed.  A simple wave to a neighbor grilling on their porch or a warm smile from a passerby creates a welcoming atmosphere.

Lawns are meticulously maintained, reflecting the pride residents take in their homes.  Fallen leaves disappear promptly, and green grass is kept neatly trimmed.  Gardens and bushes are carefully pruned, showcasing the attention to detail that permeates the neighborhood.  While the homes themselves might not be extravagant, they exude a sense of warmth and comfort, inviting you to imagine raising a family amidst this peaceful setting.

Beyond the immediate neighborhood, the community offers a sense of security and tranquility.  The county sheriff's department and jail are within walking distance, providing a reassuring presence.  The health department, just next door, further emphasizes the community's commitment to well-being.  Convenience is readily available at the nearby recycling center, which serves residents from across town.

Outdoor recreation is abundant.  Baseball and softball fields, where the cheers of fans and the announcers' voices fill the air, are located nearby, along with a small airport where the rumble of airplanes taking off and landing adds a unique soundtrack to daily life.  A local ice cream parlor is within easy walking distance, and a short bike ride takes you to the nearby park, where children can play freely.  

This is where I call home – a place where everyday life is infused with a sense of community, safety, and contentment. It's a place that embodies the values of hard work, family, and the simple pleasures of life.

original_texts:
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
The general area in which I live in can be described as your typical cookie cutter suburbia. For my neighborhood in particular, the presence of a homeowner's association is very apparent. Upon entering, you'll see nothing but well-maintained single family homes, which we can thank the homeowner's association for. The front yards are all very similar. There's a small patch of landscaped grass, some decorative pebbles, and rather short driveways. Every so often you'll see small trees as well. Everyone has a two car garage. As you continue to drive along throughout the neighborhood you'll see newly paved concrete. Despite many different families living here, the roads are in excellent condition. You won't find any potholes or anything like that here. Most of the houses are single story, but sometimes you'll see two stories as well. We don't have a typical mailbox set-up that you would expect for single family homes. There are no individual mailboxes in front of each house. Instead, it's more like apartments where there are a large grouping of mailboxes at the end of the street. Everyone uses a key to gain access their specific mailbox. And there's two larger lockers for packages. Again, you can thank the HOA and their obsession with uniformity for this. The location of my house is on the extreme edge of the nearby city, so my neighborhood can be described as part rural, part suburbs. As a result, we have a lot of land for, well, everything. There's multiple community pools to which anyone living here can access. It's well maintained and gated. And then there are various walking trails where you can walk your dog, or just go for an evening stroll by yourself. You don't have to visit a park to get your exercise in. The neighborhood is large enough that you can simply run around it and get more than enough exercise. Most of the community is made up of retired people. It's a very safe area, and everyone looks out for one another. Mixed in with that, we have a small amount of middle aged and young professionals too. In regards to the city, it's surprisingly large - at least by population - but also has a small time town feel. We have the vast majority of amenities that you come to expect and rely on. For example, we have a exactly one mall. It's not huge, but it gets the job done. For me, it takes around 15 minutes of driving to get anywhere significant, but once I do that, I am greeted with many different stores to choose from. We have everything from high end grocery stores where you can get organic food, to bargain outlets that only stock a small selection of items and has bare minimum staff to keep costs down. All in all, my neighborhood is safe, well-maintained, and pretty typical. We have a lot of nice things, like pools and walking trails. And although we aren't right next door to any sort of shopping, you can just hop in a car and go to any major chain that you'd like.
